name: chlordiazepoxide
source: Hughes LD; Palmer DS; Nigsch F and Mitchell JBO. 2008 Why are some properties more difficult to predict than others? A study of QSPR models of solubility; melting point and LogP. J. Chem. Inf. Model. 2008. 48 (1). pp 220?270

name: chlordiazepoxide
source: Hughes LD; Palmer DS; Nigsch F and Mitchell JBO. 2008 Why are some properties more difficult to predict than others? A study of QSPR models of solubility; melting point and LogP. J. Chem. Inf. Model. 2008. 48 (1). pp 220?270
Reason: The basic unit for chlordiazepoxide can be considered as benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. The compound in question has several functional groups that will modify this value. Firstly, the presence of a chlorine atom contributes to an increase in melting point due to its high electronegativity and ability to participate in intermolecular attractions (+50°C). The diazepine ring system which includes nitrogen atoms contributes significantly to the melting point as the heteroatoms introduce polarity and potential for hydrogen bonding (+100°C). Furthermore, the azomethine (imine group -C=N-) adds to the rigidity of the structure and the potential for dipole-dipole interactions (+30°C). The ester-like group with the [N+]([O-]) moiety will also raise the melting point due to its polar nature and ionic character, attracting other molecules strongly (+50°C). Also, considering steric hindrance and increased molecular weight, an additional increment (+10°C) is attributable.
